answers.text: the binary polarization of society into black and white

qas.question: What is happened in the US that did not happen in Brazil when slavery ended?
How do the US and Brazil vary after slavery has ended?

answers.text: violent racial tensions that have divided the US are notably absent in Brazil.

qas.question: Who is the Brazilian Prime Minister for racial equality?
Who is responsible for the growing pride in Brazilian communities?

context: Because of the acceptance of miscegenation, Brazil has avoided <a0_0>the binary polarization of society into black and white<a0_0/>. In addition, it abolished slavery without a <a1_0>civil war<a1_0/>. The bitter and sometimes <a2_0>violent racial tensions that have divided the US are notably absent in Brazil.<a2_0/> According to the 2010 census, 6.7% of Brazilians said they were black, compared with 6.2% in 2000, and 43.1% said they were racially mixed, up from 38.5%. In 2010, <a3_0>Elio Ferreira de Araujo<a3_0/>, Brazil's minister for racial equality, attributed the increases to growing pride among his country's <a4_0>black and indigenous communities.
